Chapter 6: Mindfulness, Mindfulness
Mindfulness gives rise to joy, but joy gives rise to sorrow, and joy gives rise to fear. If there is no joy in mindfulness,
what sorrow and what fear?
Once the Buddha was in the Jeta Grove of Anathapindika's Park in the kingdom of Shravasti.

At that time, there was a non-Buddhist brahman who had few children. He had only one son who suddenly died. Day and night he pursued and remembered him, unable to eat or drink. He took off his clothes and bared his body, crying in the cemetery, always remembering where his deceased son had come and gone.
At that time, the brahman left the city of Shravasti and went to the Jeta Grove monastery. He came to where the World-Honored One was, exchanged greetings, and sat to one side.
At that time, the World-Honored One said to the brahman:
You, brahman, your faculties are not stable and your mind is confused. What is the reason for this, that you have come to this?
The brahman said to the Buddha:
I only have one child. He has left me and died. I cannot follow him in death. I can only barely survive. How can my faculties attain concentration without being confused?
From a young age, I nurtured him, hoping he would grow up and be able to support me. Now he has abandoned me and become impermanent. My mind and thoughts are distressed and cannot let go of this.

Since his death, day and night I chase after memories of him, unable to eat or rest. I take off my clothes and expose my body, crying at the grave, always remembering where he used to go and come from.
The World-Honored One said:
So it is, brahmin!
As you say, all sorrow, grief, and suffering arise from affection and love.
The brahmin said to the Buddha:
It is not as the renunciant Gotama says that in the world, affection and love all give rise to joy and happiness.
At that time, the brahmin heard what the Buddha said, but he still did not agree. He immediately got up from his seat, bowed, and left.
Passing through a village of gamblers, he saw two people sitting opposite each other playing a game. The brahmin, upon seeing this, had this thought:
The people in the world who are highly talented, wise, knowledgeable about the past and present, and eloquent in the profound, none surpass this gambling man.
Can I now use what Gautama has said to proclaim it to those two people?
At that time, the brahman went to the two people and spoke the teachings spoken by Gautama. The gambling men said to the brahman:
It is just as you say, that when kindness and love come together, they all give rise to joy.
The brahman thought to himself:
What I think is no different from them.
He then rose from his seat, overjoyed, and left on his way.

Therefore it is said, Thinking brings joy, but also worry; thinking brings joy, but also fear.
Without thinking, there is joy - what worry, what fear?

Thinking brings fear means when a person becomes ill, those who care for the sick are always worried and afraid that the illness will not be cured, or that they may want to go to another place, or be sent on a mission by the king, or go to sea to collect treasures. The family members are afraid that the journey will not be completed. The family members advise:
There is enough wealth in the family to sustain life. Why go far to collect expensive goods through hardships?
If you go, both sides will suffer - either the journey will be safe but the stay will suffer, or the journey will suffer but the stay will be safe.
Therefore it is said, Thinking brings fear.
Without thinking, there is joy - what worry, what fear? What does this mean?
If there is no joy in thoughts, one can eliminate desire and love.
Why is this?
Because the faculty of sorrow in the desire realm is solid and very difficult to uproot, therefore it is said, What sorrow and what fear are there in the joy of no thoughts?
If there is sorrow, then there is fear. If there is no sorrow, how can there be fear?
When sorrow ends, fear ends. The ending of the five and the ending of the eighteen are just this.
Thoughts give rise to joy, thoughts give rise to sorrow, thoughts give rise to fear. Having already been separated from thoughts, one finally abandons delusion.

Therefore it is said, Having already abandoned thoughts and joy, one then discards madness and confusion.
The mind and thoughts return to correctness, all due to the power of the Buddha. Those who do not encounter the Buddha will not accomplish it.
When a person harbors sorrow and worry, worldly suffering has countless aspects.
This is due to thoughts of affection and love. Without thoughts, there is no fear.

As for when a person harbors sorrow and worry, beings of various kinds sorrow and worry day and night, facing each other and crying out, sometimes losing their minds and becoming crazed. This is all due to affection and love, longing for what is lost. Therefore it is said, when a person harbors sorrow and worry.

As for worldly suffering has countless aspects, clothes do not cover the body and food does not fill the mouth. The complexion is haggard and the body is covered in dirt. The five relatives are separated and all skills are abandoned. This is all due to affection and love causing these calamities and troubles.

When people are in the world and encounter various sufferings and afflictions, it is also due to affection and love that they are unable to let go. Therefore, it is said that the sufferings of the world are countless.

As for this is due to thinking of affection and love, the suffering of long-lasting birth and death is difficult to trace back to its root. The foolish ones dwelling in the middle do not realize it themselves. People's mutual attachment and longing are not just of one kind. They may think of their parents, siblings, relatives, and acquaintances. The dead and the living give rise to thoughts within this, chasing after each other, crying and wailing. Therefore, it is said, this is due to thinking of affection and love.
Where there is no thought, there is no fear means that when people let go of thoughts and have nothing to long for, then there is no sorrow, worry, suffering, or distress.

Those with a home worry about the home, those with wealth worry about the wealth. Those with carriages, horses, and saddles worry about the carriages, horses, and saddles. Those without carriages, horses, and saddles have nothing to long for.
What is it to have no thoughts?
It refers to the complete and permanent severance of desire and love without remainder.
Who is it that has severed desire and love?

Namely, directly attaining the state of anÄgÄmin without going through the two paths. This is called a person who has severed desire and love, has no thoughts or memories, permanently abides in the ultimate, and does not return to the desire realm. Ordinary beings who have not exhausted desire and love, although they attain the five supernatural powers, are not free from the three existences. If they lose their spiritual powers and anger and rage swell, in the time it takes to snap one's fingers they will fall back into evil destinies, and will only return to their bodies after experiencing eons.
Therefore it is said, Without thoughts, there is no fear.
Therefore, do not give rise to thoughts. Thoughts are a burden of evil.
They have no bonds, no thoughts, and no non-thoughts.

Therefore, do not give rise to thoughts. A person born in the world, due to thoughts, gives rise to affection and love, and due to thoughts, there are changes. All sorrows, worries, suffering, and distress arise from thoughts. Therefore it is said, Do not give rise to thoughts.
Thoughts are a burden of evil. How so?

It is like there being a mad man in the world who, while bearing the suffering of illness, may kill five or a hundred living beings to save the sick person, thinking he will receive a cure, not knowing that the sick person will receive countless offenses.

Or there may be a sick person who kills living beings to make offerings, also hoping to save their life. Even if the sick person is placed in a hundred-layered iron cage, in each layer they fully arrange guards to jointly verify and not allow the recorder of death to come and record the dead.
This matter is not so.
It is all due to affection and love that lead to this disaster.

Or there may be a person who knows their close relative has been gone for a long time, and comes home from afar. Thinking of that person, they kill insects and beasts to an immeasurable extent to celebrate together, accumulating the roots of misfortune.
Therefore it is said, Thinking is a burden of evil.

As for the so-called bound ones, they are those who fetter the spirit of man and do not reach the unconditioned, as explained in the sutra: When a person is tainted and attached, with the mind of love not yet exhausted, there are conditions and causes leading to the place of rebirth, either dying there and being reborn here, bound by causes and conditions, bound by bonds, bound by bonds.

It is just like a wise person and his wise disciple, if able to make a flower garland, first making a long rope as the basis, weaving the flower garland on top, using the flowers as conditions to form the flower garland.

It is the same for one whose mind of love is not yet exhausted: there are conditions and causes leading to the place of rebirth, dying there and being reborn here, one who attains the fruit of the path with conditions and causes will no longer experience these difficulties of bondage.
Therefore it is said: They then have no bonds.

No thought, no non-thought means to be free from the thought of vexation and heat, without affection or non-action, joyfully playing in the ultimate truth. Therefore, it is said no thought, no non-thought.
Thought is seeking skillful means, not yet applying expedient means to non-meaningful things,
Skillful wisdom brings great meaning, and one attains the highest honor.

Thought is seeking skillful means means wishing to cultivate unsurpassed wisdom, discerning profound meaning without deception, and having already attained this wisdom, one will never be confused. Therefore, it is said thought is seeking skillful means.
Not yet applying expedient means to non-meaningful things means what?
Non-meaningful things are not in accord with this profound meaning, causing one to fall into evil and not cultivate wholesome roots, and being ridiculed by the wise.

If one can change past mistakes, it will bring future blessings. One will then be praised by gods and humans, temporarily eliminating faults and offenses, and planting roots of goodness for future lives. Therefore, it is said, Expedient means are not established without principle.
What is meant by expedient wisdom leading to great principle?

Associating with good spiritual friends, teaching people right views and not following deviant practices, and also not engaging in heretical arts, receiving their principles. The so-called principles are the principles of uncontaminated wisdom, meditation, and contemplation. Therefore, it is said, Expedient wisdom leads to great principle.

Attaining the highest honor means that the Buddhas, the World-Honored Ones, uphold the precepts and are not negligent. Their minds are firm and do not enter the realm of evil. They always instruct sentient beings with the precepts, always seeking the three karmas. Therefore, it is said, Attaining the highest honor.
Do not associate with what is loved, nor with what is not loved,
Those who love and are mindful do not see suffering, but those who do not love and are mindful are sorrowful and distressed.
In the middle, they give rise to sorrow and distress, which consume the foundation of a person.

Those who do not wish to meet with loved ones, in the past there were two people who loved and respected each other and could not be separated. When walking, they would go together; when eating, they would enjoy it together.
Later, they were separated and each went to a different place. Later, they again thought of each other and wanted to meet. They repeatedly sent messages to call each other, wanting to be together.
If you do not come, it will increase my sorrow.
This person's enemy was close to that person's relative. When they came to call, could they go together to fulfill their request?

In the end, they followed the request and went together. Having been separated for a long time, they saw each other and were inwardly joyful. Seeing that enemy, they felt indignant and displeased. In a hidden place, the relative said meaningfully:
Why do you still associate with and follow my enemy? I do not like to see it.

Having received this message, he became even more attached and returned with her. Later, he thought of her again and sent a message to summon her. Like this, two or three times, he said to his relatives:
Why do you let him associate with that person?
That person replied:
The love has grown thick, and he forgets his previous words.
He then replied:
Thinking of the joy, but seeing evil conditions again, why do I now cling to my relatives like this? Are we not both incompatible?
He then abandoned his family, wife, and children and left home to study the Way.

For a long night, they worry and think, weep and wail, with disheveled hair, beating their chests in distress. Therefore it is said, For a long night, they worry and think.

As for if a person dwells day and night, single-mindedly severing desires for the desire realm, completely extinguishing them without remainder, diligently practicing during the day and reciting at night. Therefore it is said, if a person dwells day and night.

As for extinguishing thoughts and desires for form, having already extinguished and exhausted them, transcending existence and reaching non-existence, without further anger or resentment. Therefore it is said, extinguishing thoughts and desires for form.

How is suffering regarded as pleasure?

Pleasure means that the various faculties in the body are tranquil and undisturbed, the mind is at peace and does not give rise to chaotic thoughts, and it can also cause people to experience various afflictions, first joy and then sorrow. Therefore it is said, Suffering is regarded as pleasure.
